page.title: 05ECOLOGY AROUND BERROW
page.content: The dwellings in the area are widely spaced, giving shelter to wild life and indigenous flowers and trees. The highest part to the West is natural grassland with bracken on granite. As the land falls, gently undulating, there is mixed woodland, mainly deciduous, and finally pastureland and orchards. There is a small area of uncultivated commonland. A{wildfowl sanctuary has been set up by a stream with small pools. Many small animals and insects live in the wide roadside verges. While some hedges have been removed, most are still the ancient mixtures with deciduous trees spread along them. The weather is affected by the mass of the Malvern Hills. The area is designated as one of{outstand_ {ing natural beauty} and two fields are administered by the{Conservation Society to protect the wild flowers.
